meta.content: The performance of organic light-emitting diodes based on thermally activated delayed fluorescence emitters depends on the efficiency of reverse intersystem crossing (RISC) processes, which are pro...

The performance of organic light-emitting diodes based on thermally activated delayed fluorescence emitters depends on the efficiency of reverse intersystem crossing (RISC) processes, which are pro...
meta.name: twitter:description

meta.content: The performance of organic light-emitting diodes based on thermally activated delayed fluorescence emitters depends on the efficiency of reverse intersystem crossing (RISC) processes, which are promoted by a small energy gap between the lowest singlet (S1) and triplet (T1) excited states and large spin–orbit couplings. Recently, it was proposed that the introduction of secondary donor units into 2,3,4,5,6-penta(9H-carbazol-9-yl)benzonitrile (5CzBN) can significantly increase the mixing between triplet states with charge-transfer (CT) and local-excitation characteristics and consequently increase the spin–orbit couplings. Here, the results of long-range corrected density functional theory calculations show that the main impact on the RISC rates of substituting 5CzBN with secondary donors is due to a decrease in adiabatic singlet–triplet energy gaps and intramolecular reorganization energies rather than to a change in spin–orbit couplings. Our calculations underline that at least two singlet and three triplet excited states contribute to the ISC/RISC processes in 5CzBN and its derivatives. In addition, we find that in all emitters, the lowest singlet excited-state potential energy surface has a double-minimum shape.
meta.name: citation_abstract

head.title: Impact of secondary donor units on the excited-state properties and thermally activated delayed fluorescence (TADF) efficiency of pentacarbazole-benzonitrile emitters: The Journal of Chemical Physics: Vol 153, No 14

li.a: Up- and Down-Conversion in Molecules and Materials

div.div: I. INTRODUCTION
Section:

Purely organic molecules displaying thermally activated delayed fluorescence (TADF) have recently received considerable attention as promising emitters in the field of organic light-emitting diodes (OLEDs).
1–5
1. H. Uoyama, K. Goushi, K. Shizu, H. Nomura, and C. Adachi, “
Highly efficient organic light-emitting diodes from delayed fluorescence
,” Nature
492
, 234–
238
(2012).
https://doi.org/10.1038/nature11687
2. S. Reineke, “
Phosphorescence meets its match
,” Nat. Photonics
8
, 269–
270
(2014).
https://doi.org/10.1038/nphoton.2014.78
3. Z. Yang, Z. Mao, Z. Xie, Y. Zhang, S. Liu, J. Zhao, J. Xu, Z. Chi, and M. P. Aldred, “
Recent advances in organic thermally activated delayed fluorescence materials
,” Chem. Soc. Rev.
46
, 915–
1016
(2017).
https://doi.org/10.1039/c6cs00368k
4. Y. Liu, C. Li, Z. Ren, S. Yan, and M. R. Bryce, “
All-organic thermally activated delayed fluorescence materials for organic light-emitting diodes
,” Nat. Rev. Mater.
3
, 18020 (2018).
https://doi.org/10.1038/natrevmats.2018.20
5. Z. Cheng, Z. Li, Y. Xu, J. Liang, C. Lin, J. Wei, and Y. Wang, “
Achieving efficient blue delayed electrofluorescence by shielding acceptors with carbazole units
,” ACS Appl. Mater. Interfaces
11
, 28096–
28105
(2019).
https://doi.org/10.1021/acsami.9b07820
In such molecules, triplet excitons can be harvested through a reverse intersystem crossing (RISC) process, which corresponds to the up-conversion of these triplet excitons into singlet excitons;
6–9
6. P. K. Samanta, D. Kim, V. Coropceanu, and J.-L. Brédas, “
Up-conversion intersystem crossing rates in organic emitters for thermally activated delayed fluorescence: Impact of the nature of singlet vs triplet excited states
,” J. Am. Chem. Soc.
139
, 4042–
4051
(2017).
https://doi.org/10.1021/jacs.6b12124
7. X.-K. Chen, D. Kim, and J.-L. Brédas, “
Thermally activated delayed fluorescence (TADF) path toward efficient electroluminescence in purely organic materials: Molecular level insight
,” Acc. Chem. Res.
51
, 2215–
2224
(2018).
https://doi.org/10.1021/acs.accounts.8b00174
8. A. Pershin, D. Hall, V. Lemaur, J.-C. Sancho-Garcia, L. Muccioli, E. Zysman-Colman, D. Beljonne, and Y. Olivier, “
Highly emissive excitons with reduced exchange energy in thermally activated delayed fluorescent molecules
,” Nat. Commun.
10
, 597 (2019).
https://doi.org/10.1038/s41467-019-08495-5
9. P. Stachelek, J. S. Ward, P. L. dos Santos, A. Danos, M. Colella, N. Haase, S. J. Raynes, A. S. Batsanov, M. R. Bryce, and A. P. Monkman, “
Molecular design strategies for color tuning of blue TADF emitters
,” ACS Appl. Mater. Interfaces
11
, 27125–
27133
(2019).
https://doi.org/10.1021/acsami.9b06364
as a result, nearly 100% internal quantum efficiency can be achieved during device operation.
10–14
10. T.-L. Wu, M.-J. Huang, C.-C. Lin, P.-Y. Huang, T.-Y. Chou, R.-W. Chen-Cheng, H.-W. Lin, R.-S. Liu, and C.-H. Cheng, “
Diboron compound-based organic light-emitting diodes with high efficiency and reduced efficiency roll-off
,” Nat. Photonics
12
, 235–
240
(2018).
https://doi.org/10.1038/s41566-018-0112-9
11. Y. Kondo, K. Yoshiura, S. Kitera, H. Nishi, S. Oda, H. Gotoh, Y. Sasada, M. Yanai, and T. Hatakeyama, “
Narrowband deep-blue organic light-emitting diode featuring an organoboron-based emitter
,” Nat. Photonics
13
, 678–
682
(2019).
https://doi.org/10.1038/s41566-019-0476-5
12. J. U. Kim, I. S. Park, C.-Y. Chan, M. Tanaka, Y. Tsuchiya, H. Nakanotani, and C. Adachi, “
Nanosecond-time-scale delayed fluorescence molecule for deep-blue OLEDs with small efficiency rolloff
,” Nat. Commun.
11
, 1765 (2020).
https://doi.org/10.1038/s41467-020-15558-5
13. L.-S. Cui, A. J. Gillett, S.-F. Zhang, H. Ye, Y. Liu, X.-K. Chen, Z.-S. Lin, E. W. Evans, W. K. Myers, T. K. Ronson, H. Nakanotani, S. Reineke, J.-L. Bredas, C. Adachi, and R. H. Friend, “
Fast spin-flip enables efficient and stable organic electroluminescence from charge-transfer states
,” Nat. Photonics
14
, 636–
642
(2020).
https://doi.org/10.1038/s41566-020-0668-z
14. S. Izumi, H. F. Higginbotham, A. Nyga, P. Stachelek, N. Tohnai, P. d. Silva, P. Data, Y. Takeda, and S. Minakata, “
Thermally activated delayed fluorescent donor–acceptor–donor–acceptor π-conjugated macrocycle for organic light-emitting diodes
,” J. Am. Chem. Soc.
142
, 1482–
1491
(2020).
https://doi.org/10.1021/jacs.9b11578

According to semi-classical Marcus theory,
15
15. R. A. Marcus, “
Electron transfer reactions in chemistry. Theory and experiment
,” Rev. Mod. Phys.
65
, 599–
610
(1993).
https://doi.org/10.1103/revmodphys.65.599
the rate constant of a RISC process can be simply expressed as
k
R
I
S
C
=
A
⋅
exp
(
−
E
a
k
B
T
)
, where
A
represents a pre-factor determined by the magnitude of the spin–orbit couplings (
V
SOC
) and
E
a
denotes the activation energy. What this relation tells us is that in order to maximize the RISC rate, large
V
SOC
and small
E
a
values are needed; since
E
a
depends on the reorganization energy (
λ
) and the energy splitting between the lowest singlet excited state and the lowest triplet excited state (
Δ
E
S
1
−
T
1
), these two factors have to be minimized.

The design strategy initially applied to the development of TADF emitters mainly focused on the minimization of
Δ
E
S
1
−
T
1
by building molecules combining electron donor (D) and electron acceptor (A) moieties, which is expected to induce a large extent of spatial separation between the highest occupied molecular orbital (HOMO) and the lowest unoccupied molecular orbital (LUMO).
7,16–21
7. X.-K. Chen, D. Kim, and J.-L. Brédas, “
Thermally activated delayed fluorescence (TADF) path toward efficient electroluminescence in purely organic materials: Molecular level insight
,” Acc. Chem. Res.
51
, 2215–
2224
(2018).
https://doi.org/10.1021/acs.accounts.8b00174
16. H. Tanaka, K. Shizu, H. Miyazaki, and C. Adachi, “
Efficient green thermally activated delayed fluorescence (TADF) from a phenoxazine–triphenyltriazine (PXZ–TRZ) derivative
,” Chem. Commun.
48
, 11392–
11394
(2012).
https://doi.org/10.1039/c2cc36237f
17. K. Goushi, K. Yoshida, K. Sato, and C. Adachi, “
Organic light-emitting diodes employing efficient reverse intersystem crossing for triplet-to-singlet state conversion
,” Nat. Photonics
6
, 253–
258
(2012).
https://doi.org/10.1038/nphoton.2012.31
18. Q. Zhang, J. Li, K. Shizu, S. Huang, S. Hirata, H. Miyazaki, and C. Adachi, “
Design of efficient thermally activated delayed fluorescence materials for pure blue organic light emitting diodes
,” J. Am. Chem. Soc.
134
, 14706–
14709
(2012).
https://doi.org/10.1021/ja306538w
19. Q. Zhang, B. Li, S. Huang, H. Nomura, H. Tanaka, and C. Adachi, “
Efficient blue organic light-emitting diodes employing thermally activated delayed fluorescence
,” Nat. Photonics
8
, 326–
332
(2014).
https://doi.org/10.1038/nphoton.2014.12
20. M. Y. Wong and E. Zysman-Colman, “
Purely organic thermally activated delayed fluorescence materials for organic light-emitting diodes
,” Adv. Mater.
29
, 1605444 (2017).
https://doi.org/10.1002/adma.201605444
21. Y. Olivier, M. Moral, L. Muccioli, and J.-C. Sancho-García, “
Dynamic nature of excited states of donor–acceptor TADF materials for OLEDs: How theory can reveal structure–property relationships
,” J. Mater. Chem. C
5
, 5718–
5729
(2017).
https://doi.org/10.1039/c6tc05075a
If the S
1
and T
1
states mainly correspond to HOMO–LUMO transitions, they acquire a strong charge-transfer (CT) character, the exchange energy vanishes, and a small
Δ
E
S
1
−
T
1
can be achieved.
22
22. F. B. Dias, T. J. Penfold, and A. P. Monkman, “
Photophysics of thermally activated delayed fluorescence molecules
,” Methods Appl. Fluoresc.
5
, 012001 (2017).
https://doi.org/10.1088/2050-6120/aa537e
However, not only does the S
1
→ S
0
oscillator strength then become very limited,
7
7. X.-K. Chen, D. Kim, and J.-L. Brédas, “
Thermally activated delayed fluorescence (TADF) path toward efficient electroluminescence in purely organic materials: Molecular level insight
,” Acc. Chem. Res.
51
, 2215–
2224
(2018).
https://doi.org/10.1021/acs.accounts.8b00174
but it is also well established that the spin–orbit coupling between pure CT states is vanishingly small.
23
23. B. T. Lim, S. Okajima, A. K. Chandra, and E. C. Lim, “
Radiationless transitions in electron donor-acceptor complexes: Selection rules for S
1
→ T intersystem crossing and efficiency of S
1
→ S
0
internal conversion
,” Chem. Phys. Lett.
79
, 22–
27
(1981).
https://doi.org/10.1016/0009-2614(81)85280-3
Therefore, a hybridization between CT and local-excitation (LE) states is needed to achieve significant
V
SOC
values between the lowest singlet and triplet states (here, by local excitation, we mean an excitation involving only a donor or acceptor moiety without any charge-transfer character).

Recently, Noda
et al.
suggested that the RISC rate can be enhanced by decreasing the energy difference between the LE triplet states and the lowest CT triplet states via chemical modification of the donor or acceptor sites; indeed, such an evolution would be expected to increase the hybridization between LE and CT triplet states.
24
24. H. Noda, H. Nakanotani, and C. Adachi, “
Excited state engineering for efficient reverse intersystem crossing
,” Sci. Adv.
4
, eaao6910 (2018).
https://doi.org/10.1126/sciadv.aao6910
Based on the 2,3,4,5,6-penta(9H-carbazol-9-yl)benzonitrile (5CzBN) emitter, these authors designed four derivatives with secondary donor units, whose chemical structures are displayed in
Fig. 1
: 3Cz2DMeCzBN, formed by adding dimethyl groups to the carbazole moieties on the 3 and 5 positions of the benzene ring, and 4Cz1DPhCzBN, 3Cz2DPhCzBN, and 2Cz3DPhCzBN, where two phenyl rings are added to the carbazoles in positions 5, 3 and 5, and 2, 4, and 6 of the benzene ring, respectively. Noda
et al.
reported that, e.g., in the case of 2Cz3DPhCzBN, the RISC rate is about five times larger than that in 5CzBN.
24
24. H. Noda, H. Nakanotani, and C. Adachi, “
Excited state engineering for efficient reverse intersystem crossing
,” Sci. Adv.
4
, eaao6910 (2018).
https://doi.org/10.1126/sciadv.aao6910

FIG. 1.
Chemical structures of (a) 5CzBN and its derivatives incorporating dimethyl (DMeCz) or diphenyl (DPhCz) secondary donors on the carbazoles: (b) 3Cz2DMeCzBN, (c) 4Cz1DPhCzBN, (d) 3Cz2DPhCzBN, and (e) 2Cz3DPhCzBN.

To explore whether an increase in CT–LE hybridization of the lowest excited states is actually the main reason for the increase in the RISC rates measured by Noda
et al.
, we decided to undertake a theoretical investigation of the effect of secondary donor units on the molecular excitation energies, nature of excited states, and RISC/ISC rates in 5CzBN and its four derivatives. Our results are described below and discussed in comparison with the experimental data of Noda
et al.
24
24. H. Noda, H. Nakanotani, and C. Adachi, “
Excited state engineering for efficient reverse intersystem crossing
,” Sci. Adv.
4
, eaao6910 (2018).
https://doi.org/10.1126/sciadv.aao6910
II. COMPUTATIONAL METHODS
Section:

We carried out density functional theory (DFT) calculations at the optimally tuned long-range corrected ωB97XD/6-31G
**
level of theory.
25
25. J.-D. Chai and M. Head-Gordon, “
Long-range corrected hybrid density functionals with damped atom–atom dispersion corrections
,” Phys. Chem. Chem. Phys.
10
, 6615–
6620
(2008).
https://doi.org/10.1039/b810189b
All DFT calculations were performed with the Gaussian 09 program.
26
26. M. J. Frisch, G. W. Trucks, H. B. Schlegel, G. E. Scuseria, M. A. Robb, J. R. Cheeseman, G. Scalmani, V. Barone, G. A. Petersson, H. Nakatsuji, X. Li, M. Caricato, A. V. Marenich, J. Bloino, B. G. Janesko, R. Gomperts, B. Mennucci, H. P. Hratchian, J. V. Ortiz, A. F. Izmaylov, J. L. Sonnenberg, D. Williams-Young, F. Ding, F. Lipparini, F. Egidi, J. Goings, B. Peng, A. Petrone, T. Henderson, D. Ranasinghe, V. G. Zakrzewski, J. Gao, N. Rega, G. Zheng, W. Liang, M. Hada, M. Ehara, K. Toyota, R. Fukuda, J. Hasegawa, M. Ishida, T. Nakajima, Y. Honda, O. Kitao, H. Nakai, T. Vreven, K. Throssell, J. A. Montgomery, Jr., J. E. Peralta, F. Ogliaro, M. J. Bearpark, J. J. Heyd, E. N. Brothers, K. N. Kudin, V. N. Staroverov, T. A. Keith, R. Kobayashi, J. Normand, K. Raghavachari, A. P. Rendell, J. C. Burant, S. S. Iyengar, J. Tomasi, M. Cossi, J. M. Millam, M. Klene, C. Adamo, R. Cammi, J. W. Ochterski, R. L. Martin, K. Morokuma, O. Farkas, J. B. Foresman, and D. J. Fox, Gaussian 09, Revision A.02,
Wallingford, CT
, 2009.
For the sake of simplicity, the effect of the dielectric medium on the excited states was not considered. The range-separation parameters (ω) were optimized for the isolated 5CzBN molecule and its derivatives. Since introducing secondary donor units extend wavefunction delocalization, the tuned range-separation parameter ω becomes slightly smaller upon substitution (see
Table I
). The calculations for the excited states were performed at the time-dependent DFT (TDA-TDDFT) level, within the Tamm–Dancoff approximation.
27,28
27. S. Hirata and M. Head-Gordon, “
Time-dependent density functional theory within the Tamm–Dancoff approximation
,” Chem. Phys. Lett.
314
, 291–
299
(1999).
https://doi.org/10.1016/s0009-2614(99)01149-5
28. J. S. Sears, T. Koerzdoerfer, C.-R. Zhang, and J.-L. Brédas, “
Communication: Orbital instabilities and triplet states from time-dependent density functional theory and long-range corrected functionals
,” J. Chem. Phys.
135
, 151103 (2011).
https://doi.org/10.1063/1.3656734
The geometries of the ground state and the excited states were optimized using DFT and TDA-TDDFT, respectively. The spin–orbit couplings were calculated with the PySOC code.
29
29. X. Gao, S. Bai, D. Fazzi, T. Niehaus, M. Barbatti, and W. Thiel, “
Evaluation of spin-orbit couplings with linear-response time-dependent density functional methods
,” J. Chem. Theory Comput.
13
, 515–
524
(2017).
https://doi.org/10.1021/acs.jctc.6b00915
The intramolecular reorganization energies for singlet–triplet transitions were calculated from the adiabatic potential energy surfaces of these states.
30
30. V. Coropceanu, J. Cornil, D. A. da Silva Filho, Y. Olivier, R. Silbey, and J.-L. Brédas, “
Charge transport in organic semiconductors
,” Chem. Rev.
107
, 926–
952
(2007).
https://doi.org/10.1021/cr050140x
Analyses of the natural transition orbitals (NTOs) were performed to characterize the nature of the excited states. The CT and LE contributions to each excited state were further evaluated by calculating the donor and acceptor fragment charges using the ADCH (atomic dipole moment corrected Hirshfeld charge)
31
31. T. Lu and F. Chen, “
Atomic dipole moment corrected Hirshfeld population method
,” J. Theor. Comput. Chem.
11
, 163–
183
(2012).
https://doi.org/10.1142/s0219633612500113
model using the Multiwfn program;
32
32. T. Lu and F. Chen, “
Multiwfn: A multifunctional wavefunction analyzer
,” J. Comput. Chem.
33
, 580–
592
(2012).
https://doi.org/10.1002/jcc.22885
in each instance, the carbazole-based units are assigned as the donor fragment, and benzonitrile is assigned as the acceptor fragment.

TABLE I.
Vertical excitation energies (in eV) of the lowest five singlet and lowest five triplet excited states in 5CzBN and its derivatives. The oscillator strengths of the singlet states are given in parentheses. The ω values (in bohr
−1
) refer to the optimally tuned range-separation parameters.

The ISC/RISC rate constants were evaluated via the semi-classical Marcus equation
15
15. R. A. Marcus, “
Electron transfer reactions in chemistry. Theory and experiment
,” Rev. Mod. Phys.
65
, 599–
610
(1993).
https://doi.org/10.1103/revmodphys.65.599

g

O

ℏ
,

B

,

,

, and ∆
G
° represent the reduced Planck constant, Boltzmann constant, temperature, spin–orbit coupling, reorganization energy, and change in free energy, respectively. The
g
parameter accounts for the degeneracy of the initial (reactant) state and is set to 1 and 3 for the calculations of ISC and RISC rates, respectively. ∆
G
° was obtained as the difference between the energies of the respective initial and final singlet and triplet states. When considering the involvement of several excited states into the rate calculations, the contribution of each state (
E
i
) to the rate was weighted according to the respective Boltzmann thermal factor,
P
i
=
exp
(

E

B
T
)
/
Z
, where
Z
is the partition function.

The radiative decay rate constants were calculated according to the Einstein equation
33
33. R. C. Hilborn, “
Einstein coefficients, cross sections,
f
values, dipole moments, and all that
,” Am. J. Phys.
50
, 982–
986
(1982).
https://doi.org/10.1119/1.12937

,

,

(

), and

denote the vacuum permittivity, speed of light, S
1

1
state, respectively. The local-field correction factor,
f

2
9
, accounts for the local electric field effect and is evaluated here according to the Lorentz virtual cavity model;
34
34. D. Toptygin, “
Effects of the solvent refractive index and its dispersion on the radiative decay rate and extinction coefficient of a fluorescent solute
,” J. Fluoresc.
13
, 201–
219
(2003).
https://doi.org/10.1023/a:1025033731377
the value of
n
was set to 1.50, which corresponds to the refractive index of toluene. As in the case of the ISC/RISC rates, the Boltzmann thermal population was also considered in the calculations of the radiative decay rates.
III. RESULTS AND DISCUSSION
Section:

The molecules under investigation consist of five donor sites interacting with a single acceptor site. Therefore, in the zeroth-order approximation, there are five diabatic CT singlet states and five diabatic CT triplet states. The electronic interactions among the donor sites and their positional non-equivalence result in the lifting of the degeneracy of the diabatic states and the formation of five adiabatic states for each spin manifold. The energy splitting among the lowest five singlet or lowest five triplet states is about 0.3 eV (see
Table I
). Only the lowest two singlet states (S
1
and S
2
) carry a significant oscillator strength. The energy splitting of S
1
and S
2
, based on vertical transitions, does not exceed 0.1 eV and can be as small as 0.01 eV in the case of 2Cz3DPhCzBN. The other singlet states have significantly higher energies, which would prevent their thermal population at room temperature; therefore, they are not explicitly considered in the remainder of this work.

In all molecules, there appear three triplet states below the S
2
state. The energies of the lowest two singlet and lowest three triplet excited states are plotted in
Fig. 2
. In comparison with 5CzBN, the introduction of secondary donor units leads to a reduction in the S
1
energy by about 0.07 eV–0.18 eV and in the T
1
energy by about 0.03 eV–0.13 eV. As in the case of the S
1
and S
2
states, a very small energy difference, not exceeding 0.05 eV, is found between the vertical energies of the T
1
and T
2
states. The introduction of the secondary donors reduces the vertical singlet–triplet energy splitting
Δ
E
S
1
−
T
1
by 0.02 eV–0.05 eV. These results are fully consistent with the experimental differences in fluorescence and phosphorescence onset energies measured in dilute toluene solutions.
24
24. H. Noda, H. Nakanotani, and C. Adachi, “
Excited state engineering for efficient reverse intersystem crossing
,” Sci. Adv.
4
, eaao6910 (2018).
https://doi.org/10.1126/sciadv.aao6910

FIG. 2.
Illustration of the vertical excitation energies calculated for 5CzBN and its derivatives.

The effect of the secondary donor units on the nature of the excited states was examined via a natural transition orbital (NTO) analysis, see
Fig. 3
and Fig. S1. The results indicate that in all molecules, the lowest two singlet states and the lowest three triplet states are CT–LE hybrid states with a dominant CT character; the holes are distributed over several carbazole units, while the electrons are mainly localized on the benzonitrile moiety. While the introduction of the secondary donor units influences the hole delocalization pattern, the percentages of CT contributions to these excited states are estimated to be hardly affected, see
Table II
. The CT contributions are in the range of 60%–70%, and there are only minor variations in the CT amount for a given singlet or triplet excited state across the investigated systems.

FIG. 3.
Hole and electron natural transition orbitals (NTOs) in the S
1
and T
1
states of 5CzBN and its derivatives, based on the optimized ground-state geometries.

TABLE II.
Calculated charge-transfer (CT) and local-excitation (LE) contributions (in %) to the S
1
, S
2
, T
1
, T
2
, and T
3
states of 5CzBN and its derivatives.

We also considered the impact of the secondary donors on the energy of the lowest LE state. The NTOs of the lowest triplet LE state in 5CzBN and its derivatives are displayed in
Fig. 4
, and the corresponding energies are collected in
Table III
. Upon adding the secondary donors, the energy of the lowest LE triplet state decreases in the same way as the energies of the lowest singlet and triplet CT states. As a result, the energy differences between the lowest triplet LE and the triplet CT excited state, ΔE(
3
LE–
3
CT), remain nearly identical across the series of emitters.

FIG. 4.
Hole and electron natural transition orbitals (NTOs) in the lowest triplet LE state of 5CzBN and its derivatives.

TABLE III.
Calculated energies of the lowest singlet charge-transfer (
1
CT), triplet charge-transfer (
3
CT), and triplet local-excitation (
3
LE) states and their differences for 5CzBN and its derivatives.

The calculated spin–orbit couplings are given in
Table IV
. In all cases, the largest
V
SOC
values (on the order of 1 cm
−1
) are found between the S
1
and T
1
states; moderate
V
SOC
values are also obtained between the S
2
and T
2
states. In addition, significant spin–orbit couplings are calculated for the S
2
↔ T
1
and S
1
↔ T
3
transitions. Overall, as seen from
Table IV
, our calculations indicate that the spin–orbit couplings between the lowest singlet and triplet states are very similar for all investigated systems. Thus, our results do not support the suggestion that the addition of secondary donor units to 5CzBN could increase the spin–orbit couplings.

TABLE IV.
Spin–orbit couplings,
V
SOC
(in cm
−1
), computed between the lowest triplet and singlet states of 5CzBN and its derivatives. The calculations are performed at the ground-state geometries.

It is also useful to note that in many earlier theoretical models, the T
2
state was explicitly considered in addition to the T
1
and S
1
states in order to rationalize the RISC rates.
6,35–37
6. P. K. Samanta, D. Kim, V. Coropceanu, and J.-L. Brédas, “
Up-conversion intersystem crossing rates in organic emitters for thermally activated delayed fluorescence: Impact of the nature of singlet vs triplet excited states
,” J. Am. Chem. Soc.
139
, 4042–
4051
(2017).
https://doi.org/10.1021/jacs.6b12124
35. L. Lin, J. Fan, and C.-K. Wang, “
Theoretical perspective for internal quantum efficiency of thermally activated delayed fluorescence emitter in solid phase: A QM/MM study
,” Org. Electron.
51
, 349–
356
(2017).
https://doi.org/10.1016/j.orgel.2017.09.021
36. L. Lin, J. Fan, L. Cai, and C.-K. Wang, “
Excited state dynamics of new-type thermally activated delayed fluorescence emitters: Theoretical view of light-emitting mechanism
,” Mol. Phys.
116
, 19–
28
(2018).
https://doi.org/10.1080/00268976.2017.1362119
37. P. Pander, R. Motyka, P. Zassowski, M. K. Etherington, D. Varsano, T. J. da Silva, M. J. Caldas, P. Data, and A. P. Monkman, “
Thermally activated delayed fluorescence mediated through the upper triplet state manifold in non-charge-transfer star-shaped triphenylamine–carbazole molecules
,” J. Phys. Chem. C
122
, 23934–
23942
(2018).
https://doi.org/10.1021/acs.jpcc.8b07610
However, our results show that in TADF emitters with multiple components (such as here with five carbazole donor moieties), the situation could be even more complex; thus, the theoretical models used to describe the ISC and RISC rates should in fact involve several triplet and singlet states.

Up to now, the discussion was based on the vertical excitation energies. We now consider the impact of geometry relaxations. The adiabatic energies of the S
1
and T
1
states obtained by means of excited-state geometry optimizations are collected in
Table V
. In the case of adiabatic excitation energies, the introduction of secondary donors decreases the S
1
and T
1
energies by about 0.06 eV–0.18 eV and 0.05 eV–0.11 eV, respectively. Upon geometry relaxations, however, the adiabatic singlet–triplet energy difference
Δ
E
S
1
−
T
1
*
remains nearly the same, ∼0.10 eV, for all derivatives except for 2Cz3DPhCzBN where
Δ
E
S
1
−
T
1
*
comes down to 0.04 eV.

TABLE V.
Adiabatic energies of the triplet and singlet [E
*
(T
1
) and E
*
(S
1
)] states, energy differences between the S
1
and T
1
states (
Δ
E
S
1
−
T
1
*
), and reorganization energies (
λ
S
1
−
T
1
) of the relevant singlet–triplet transitions for 5CzBN and its derivatives (all units are in eV).

The geometry optimizations also bring an important feature that up to now has not been fully addressed in the literature, the fact that the excited states of multi-component TADF molecules such as 5CzBN can exhibit a broken-symmetry geometry. Indeed, 5CzBN and its derivatives except for 4Cz1DPhCzBN fall in the C
2
symmetry point group, as does 4CzIPN.
38
38. E. W. Evans, Y. Olivier, Y. Puttisong, W. K. Myers, T. J. H. Hele, S. M. Menke, T. H. Thomas, D. Credgington, D. Beljonne, R. H. Friend, and N. C. Greenham, “
Vibrationally assisted intersystem crossing in benchmark thermally activated delayed fluorescence molecules
,” J. Phys. Chem. C
9
, 4053–
4058
(2018).
https://doi.org/10.1021/acs.jpclett.8b01556
The ground-state geometries of all systems here are optimized to be C
2
-symmetric; as a result, the NTOs for the vertical S
1
and T
1
states in
Fig. 3
are distributed symmetrically over the entire molecule. Upon relaxation, the geometries of the S
1
state in all emitters and those of the T
1
state in 3Cz2DMeCzBN and 3Cz2DPhCzBN acquire a broken-symmetry character, as seen from the asymmetric distributions of the NTOs over the molecular structures in
Fig. 5
. The C–N bond lengths are identical in the ground-state geometry, while in the broken geometry, they differ by up to ∼0.02 Å, see Fig. S2. While unfortunately the optimizations of the S
2
, T
2
, and T
3
geometries did not converge, we expect from symmetry considerations that S
2
[T
2
] should be localized on the molecular sites opposite to the sites where S
1
[T
1
] is localized; thus, the first excited-state adiabatic energy potential for singlet and triplet states should exhibit two equivalent minima. We recall that even the difference between the vertical S
1
and S
2
(T
1
and T
2
) energies is very small, which supports our assumption of degeneracy of the S
1
and S
2
(T
1
and T
2
) adiabatic states. In such instances, intra-molecular energy transfer processes could take place and have a significant impact on the photophysical molecular properties. Further investigations of this issue are clearly warranted.

FIG. 5.
Hole and electron natural transition orbitals (NTOs) in the S
1
and T
1
states of 5CzBN and its derivatives, based on the excited-state optimized geometries.

We also computed the reorganization energies,
λ
S
1
T
1
, related to the ISC/RISC transitions between the S
1
and T
1
states; the results are given in
Table V
. The introduction of secondary donors leads to a substantial decrease in the intra-molecular reorganization energy as
λ
S
1
T
1
goes from 0.15 eV in 5CzBN down to 0.08 eV–0.09 eV in its derivatives. The main reason is the extension of the donor size. We note that the decrease in
λ
S
1
T
1
agrees very well with the reduction in the activation energy observed experimentally upon addition of secondary donors.
24
24. H. Noda, H. Nakanotani, and C. Adachi, “
Excited state engineering for efficient reverse intersystem crossing
,” Sci. Adv.
4
, eaao6910 (2018).
https://doi.org/10.1126/sciadv.aao6910

Finally, we estimated the radiative (
k
r
), RISC (
k
RISC
), and ISC (
k
ISC
) rate constants at 300 K based on the adiabatic energies of the S
1
and T
1
states, see
Table VI
. As we mentioned earlier, we were unable to obtain the adiabatic energies of the S
2
, T
2
, and T
3
states, as well as the reorganization energies except for those related to the S
1
↔ T
1
transitions. Thus, we had to rely on the following reasonable assumptions: We considered that S
1
and S
2
are energetically degenerate and T
1
and T
2
are as well; we also considered that the T
3
–T
2
energetic separation is the same as in the case of the vertical energies. In the calculations of the
k
RISC
and
k
ISC
rates, 0.1 eV was added to
λ
S
1
−
T
1
to account for the medium contribution to the reorganization energy. We also assumed that
λ
S
1
−
T
3
is equal to
λ
S
1
−
T
1
; however, we checked that having
λ
S
1
−
T
3
different from
λ
S
1
−
T
1
within a range of ±0.1 eV has only a minor effect on the computed
k
RISC
and
k
ISC
values. The calculated radiative rate constants for all molecules are comparable, which is in agreement with the experimental observations.
24
24. H. Noda, H. Nakanotani, and C. Adachi, “
Excited state engineering for efficient reverse intersystem crossing
,” Sci. Adv.
4
, eaao6910 (2018).
https://doi.org/10.1126/sciadv.aao6910

TABLE VI.
Calculated radiative decay (
k
r
), RISC (
k
RISC
), and ISC (
k
ISC
) rate constants in 5CzBN and its derivatives compared to the experimental values.
24
24. H. Noda, H. Nakanotani, and C. Adachi, “
Excited state engineering for efficient reverse intersystem crossing
,” Sci. Adv.
4
, eaao6910 (2018).
https://doi.org/10.1126/sciadv.aao6910

According to our calculations, the increase in RISC rates upon going from 5CzBN to its four derivatives comes from (i) the reduced adiabatic singlet–triplet energy gaps and (ii) the decrease in intramolecular reorganization energies due to the bulkier nature of the donor moieties upon introduction of the secondary donors (a similar evolution was also observed in 5CzBN upon introducing
tert
-butyl units).
39
39. D. Zhang, M. Cai, Y. Zhang, D. Zhang, and L. Duan, “
Sterically shielded blue thermally activated delayed fluorescence emitters with improved efficiency and stability
,” Mater. Horiz.
3
, 145–
151
(2016).
https://doi.org/10.1039/c5mh00258c
The calculated RISC rates reproduce very well the experimental trends, even though they are somewhat larger than the experimental values. Evidently, the calculation of the adiabatic energies of all relevant states and the estimation of all related reorganization energies are needed to provide more accurate theoretical results. In addition, it should be borne in mind that the effect of the dielectric medium should be fully taken into account since it can not only increase the reorganization energies but also impact the T
1
, T
2
, T
3
, S
1
, and S
2
relative energies.

Overall, our results confirm that considering only the S
1
–T
1
transition is far from sufficient to understand the RISC processes in multi-component TADF emitters where two or more donor and/or acceptor units are present and, thus, two or more (nearly) degenerate singlet and triplet excited states are expected to play a role. Thus, in the case of TADF molecules such as 5CzBN and its derivatives, which have several donor units and often a symmetric structure, we should take into account not only the S
1
–T
1
transitions but also those involving states such as S
2
, T
2
, and T
3
in order to appropriately describe the RISC rates and reveal accurately the mechanisms of the up-conversion processes.
IV. CONCLUSIONS
Section:

We have evaluated the impact of the introduction of secondary donor units in the 5CzBN emitter on the excited-state energies, nature of the excited states, radiative rates, and RISC/ISC rates using long-range corrected density functional theory at the ωB97XD/6-31G
**
level. The calculations indicate that the lowest two singlet and lowest three triplet states in 5CzBN and its derivatives are LE–CT hybrid states with a dominant CT character.

Our results show that upon addition of secondary donors to 5CzBN, the energies of the lowest singlet and triplet CT states substantially decrease, while the variations in the singlet–triplet energy gap are very small. A similar decrease in energy was also found for the lowest LE triplet state, with the energy difference between the lowest LE and CT triplet states remaining nearly the same across the molecular series. In the emitters with C
2
-symmetry in their ground state, the relaxed geometries in the S
1
and T
1
states acquire a broken-symmetry character, which results in the lowest singlet potential energy surface presenting a double-minimum shape; the potential impact of this feature on the TADF properties remains to be investigated.

The calculated RISC rates are in good agreement with the experimental data. We attribute the increase in RISC rates when going from 5CzBN to its derivatives to the decrease in the adiabatic singlet–triplet energy gaps as well as in the intra-molecular reorganization energies, rather than to a change in spin–orbit couplings as was suggested earlier.

Our work thus underlines the following:
(i)
In addition to small singlet–triplet energy gaps, small intramolecular reorganization energies are needed to improve the TADF efficiency.
(ii)
In TADF emitters with multiple donor and/or acceptor sites, several singlet and triplet states can contribute to the ISC/RISC processes. Therefore, a detailed characterization of all these states and of their related spin–orbit couplings and reorganization energies is necessary to reach an accurate theoretical description of the up-conversion mechanisms.
SUPPLEMENTARY MATERIAL
Section:

supplementary-material.div:
The
supplementary material
includes a description of the natural transition orbitals (NTOs) in the S
2
, T
2
, and T
3
states of 5CzIPN and its derivatives (Fig. S1) and of the C–N bond lengths for the donor moieties on opposite sides of 5CzBN and its derivatives, based on the optimized S
1
geometries (Fig. S2).

The data that support the findings of this study are available from the corresponding author upon reasonable request.
